legal.title: Legal Protection
legal.description: This section outlines the legal framework for hate speech in various countries. The goal is to help users understand their rights, identify responsible official bodies, and distinguish between illegal speech and freedom of expression.

map.title: International Legal Framework

hateSpeechContent.definitionText: is any expression that incites violence, discrimination, or hostility against individuals or groups based on their identity or belonging, such as:
hateSpeechContent.keyElementsText: Hate speech must include incitement or a call for violence/discrimination, not just the expression of an opposing opinion.
whatWeMonitor: calls for extermination or collective violence
intentional misinformation that harms a specific group
hateSpeechContent.whatWeDoNotTitle: What is not subject to legal follow-up?
whatWeDoNot: personal disputes not related to hate speech
non-public content such as private messages
reports without evidence or a verifiable link
hateSpeechContent.differenceTitle: Hate Speech vs. Freedom of Expression
protectedItems: objective criticism of ideas and beliefs
constructive critique of policies and practices
notProtectedItems: incitement to violence against a group
defamation of a group based on identity
spreading false information to stir hatred
hateSpeechContent.boundaryText: Freedom of expression ends where incitement to hatred or violence begins. You may criticize ideas, but you cannot incite harm against people because of who they are.

documentationContent.proTipText: Always take a full-page screenshot rather than cropping a portion. Full context increases credibility and legal admissibility.

lawsContent.title: International Laws Against Hate Speech
lawsContent.description: The legal framework for combating hate speech varies from country to country, but most democratic nations criminalize incitement to violence and hatred against individuals or groups based on protected characteristics such as race, religion, nationality, or ethnicity.
lawsContent.sectionInfo: In this section: You will find detailed legal information for each country, including applicable laws, the definition of hate speech, and the official authorities responsible for receiving reports. Click on any country in the map below to see details.

Use archiving tools and keep multiple copies.

faqs.q: Is my data safe when using the tool?
faqs.a: Yes. The initiative stores input texts to improve monitoring and analysis accuracy, without linking them to users or their identities. Data related to reports is stored with high privacy measures and used exclusively for legal and research purposes related to combating hate speech.

faqs.q: How can I report offensive content?
faqs.a: After analyzing the text, the classification result is shown to the user. If the content contains hate speech or dangerous incitement, a legal report can be generated according to the laws of the chosen country, whether inside or outside Syria. Reports are sent to competent authorities or can be downloaded and used directly in the reporting process.

faqs.q: What is hate speech? And how do we distinguish it from freedom of expression?
faqs.a: Hate speech is expression that targets an individual or group based on their religious, sectarian, gender, or regional identity, and is based on incitement, stigmatization, or dehumanization. Freedom of expression remains protected unless it turns into incitement or collective abuse. This distinction helps protect public debate without normalizing verbal violence.

faqs.q: What happens after submitting a formal report?
faqs.a: A legal report is generated containing the violating text, risk level analysis, and the legal basis related to the chosen country. It is then forwarded to the initiative's partners or downloaded directly by the user for use in reporting to competent authorities.

faqs.q: What should I do if I receive a direct threat?
faqs.a: It is advised to save full evidence (text, link, date), analyze the content via the tool, generate a legal report, and then inform competent authorities in the country of residence. You can also contact the initiative for technical or guidance support.

faqContent.helpText: Contact us directly and we will help you understand the appropriate legal procedures for your case.

protection.title: Digital Protection ‚Äì How to Protect Yourself from Hate Speech?
protection.subtitle: The digital space is witnessing an escalation in sectarian and inflammatory speech, and daily content is turning into a tool that reshapes relationships between components and groups. This section is a practical guide to help you confront this speech, protect yourself and your surroundings, and contribute to building a safer digital environment.

awareness.title: üß† Understand & Analyze - Hate Speech Awareness
awareness.intro: Before you can protect yourself, you must understand how hate is built and how it spreads. This section helps you develop a 'critical eye' to detect harmful speech before you are affected by it.

timeline.title: üîç Observe how hate is built... so you can stop it
timeline.intro: Hate speech doesn't appear suddenly; it goes through three clear stages:

1.title: Dehumanization & Preparation
1.desc: Small words are used to dehumanize the other: 'insects', 'germs', 'traitors'... simple words but they prepare the ground for accepting violence.

2.title: Media Justification
2.desc: This language is recycled through media pages or influential accounts, turning into 'legitimate' or 'socially acceptable' speech.

3.title: Rapid Spread & Contagion
3.desc: It spreads via hashtags, memes, short videos, and fake accounts, reaching a wide audience that repeats it unconsciously.

timeline.tip: üí° Tip: When you understand these stages, recognizing harmful speech becomes an automatic step that helps you stop it and not engage in it.

checklist.title: ‚ùì Analyze content before interacting with it
checklist.intro: When viewing a post regarding a group, sect, or region, use this quick filter to determine its nature:

questions.0: Does it target identity? (Instead of individual action)
questions.1: Does it include dehumanization or insults?
questions.2: Does it drive you to fear or anger instead of understanding?
questions.3: Does it generalize to a whole group based on an individual act?
questions.4: Does it use inflammatory or violent language?

results.high: üö® High Probability - This is likely hate speech

checklist.contextAlert: ‚ö†Ô∏è Clear warning sign in Syrian context: Much content starts with a normal sentence and ends with a complete generalization: 'All Druze...', 'All Sunnis...', 'Alawites always...'. This jump from individual to group is a strong indicator of hate speech.

misinfo.title: üõë Avoid falling for misinformation that creates hate
misinfo.intro: Before sharing any post, pay attention to four mechanisms used daily to create sectarian and regional narratives:

framing.name: Framing
framing.def: When a story is presented from only one angle to reach a predetermined conclusion.
framing.ex: Showing one incident to represent the 'nature' of an entire group

generalization.name: Generalization
generalization.def: When an individual's action (one incident) turns into 'group traits' or a characteristic of an entire region.
generalization.ex: 'All people of region X are...' based on one person's act

halfTruth.name: Half-Truth
halfTruth.def: When content presents correct information but hides the rest of the context to create a misleading and inflammatory narrative.
halfTruth.ex: Mentioning part of the event and hiding the full context

echoChambers.name: Echo Chambers
echoChambers.def: When the platform shows you content that resembles your convictions only, making you feel that 'everyone' thinks like you.
echoChambers.ex: In Syria, echo chambers are responsible for creating waves of collective anger that amplify rumors

misinfo.tip: üí° Remember: When you recognize these patterns, deconstructing hateful speech becomes easier than resharing it.

faq.title: Frequently Asked Questions
faq.subtitle: Answers to the most frequently asked questions about the initiative and how it works

items.a: The Baligh Initiative is a civic-tech project aimed at monitoring and combating violence and hate speech in the Syrian digital space. The initiative relies on combining automated text analysis with human review, and is based on research and legal expertise to provide accurate content classification and reliable reporting services.

Analysis begins with an AI model trained on Syrian dialects and context to determine the severity of the speech. In complex or sensitive cases, a specialized team reviews the results to ensure accuracy and minimize bias. This dual approach combines the speed of technology with the expertise of specialists.

items.q: Is my data safe when using the tool?
items.a: Yes. The initiative stores input texts to improve monitoring and analysis accuracy, without linking them to users or their identities. Data related to reports is stored with high privacy measures and used exclusively for legal and research purposes related to combating hate speech.

items.q: How can I report offensive content?
items.a: After analyzing the text, the classification result is shown to the user. If the content contains hate speech or dangerous incitement, a legal report can be generated according to the laws of the chosen country, whether inside or outside Syria. Reports are sent to competent authorities or can be downloaded and used directly in the reporting process.

items.q: What is hate speech? And how do we distinguish it from freedom of expression?
items.a: Hate speech is expression that targets an individual or group based on their religious, sectarian, gender, or regional identity, and is based on incitement, stigmatization, or dehumanization. Freedom of expression remains protected unless it turns into incitement or collective abuse. This distinction helps protect public debate without normalizing verbal violence.

items.q: Does the analysis rely entirely on AI?
items.a: No. AI is an assisting tool, not the final arbiter. The model performs the initial classification, while sensitive cases are reviewed by humans to ensure higher accuracy in understanding the context, language, and narratives prevalent in Syrian discourse.

items.q: What should I do if I think the system made a mistake?
items.a: You can submit a request for manual review. The text and context are re-read, and the classification is corrected if an error is proven. This process aims to build user trust and continuously develop the system.

items.q: What happens after submitting a formal report?
items.a: A legal report is generated containing the violating text, risk level analysis, and the legal basis related to the chosen country. It is then forwarded to the initiative's partners or downloaded directly by the user for use in reporting to competent authorities.

items.q: Do I need to create an account?
items.a: No. Everyone can use the analysis tool without registration. An account becomes useful for those who wish to save a record of reports or track them.

items.q: Can the tool be used for research or educational purposes?
items.a: Yes. The tool is used in training programs, research on digital media and civil peace, and in building anti-hate speech curricula. The initiative can provide technical or methodological support to interested parties.

items.q: Is the tool only for Syrians?
items.a: Although the tool is specifically developed for Syrian dialects and narratives, its use is available to anyone who wishes to understand hate speech in Arabic or monitor incitement patterns in similar contexts.

items.q: What type of content cannot be analyzed currently?
items.a: The system cannot analyze non-textual images, long videos, or audio recordings. Work is underway to add OCR and audio processing tools to expand the scope of analysis in the future.

items.q: Why should hate speech be reported?
items.a: Because hate speech is not just words, but a precursor to violence and division. Numerous experiences in conflict countries have shown that ignoring this speech leads to mass crimes and threatens civil peace. Reporting is a preventive practice aimed at protecting society and promoting accountability.

items.q: What should I do if I receive a direct threat?
items.a: It is advised to save full evidence (text, link, date), analyze the content via the tool, generate a legal report, and then inform competent authorities in the country of residence. You can also contact the initiative for technical or guidance support.

The initiative operates within a wide cooperation network including lawyers inside and outside Syria, civil society organizations, media institutions, and researchers in digital rights fields, allowing it to combine legal expertise, technical capability, and research knowledge in a comprehensive approach to hate speech.

items.q: How can I join or volunteer?
items.a: You can contact us via the 'Join Us' page. The initiative welcomes volunteers in the fields of monitoring, research, design, translation, and legal analysis.

items.q: Is the initiative a political entity?
items.a: No. The initiative is completely independent and does not belong to any political or partisan entity. Its goal is to curb hate speech, promote citizenship values, and build a safe and responsible digital space.
